Background

The University of Virginia Library, like many institutions, faced a pair of interrelated problems. Firstly, the indexing of content in our digital object repositories was accomplished by piecework batch-processing scripts written by technicians whose expertise does not extend to curating the materials in our collections. Secondly, our presentation of those materials was and is increasingly dependent on index records.

In order to attack both of these problems, we decided to construct an indexing system that maintains workflow configuration in the repositories themselves (whcih will eventually allow for it to be altered via user-friendly tools acting on the repositories) and does indexing in an event-driven manner that is triggered by changed in the repository state. This allows for curatorial personel to make changes to the repository contents and have those changes propagate into the indexes that support presentation without intervention from technicians. Because we maintain the indexing configurations in the repositories where we can rely on Fedora's notification system, we can also be sure that when the indexing transforms change, the results propagate across all the affected objects and index records automatically.
